description: From Latin recēdō  +‎ -ive, or directly from New Latin recessīvus.

adjectives.description: recessive (comparative more recessive, superlative most recessive)

entries.meaning: (genetics) Able to be masked by a dominant allele or trait.
examples: The Lydenburg male and the other two females have the infuscate pattern definitely more recessive and less evident, although traceable.

entries.meaning: (by extension) Not dominant; whose effect is masked by stronger effects.
examples: The worker–client relationship is more recessive and has a more catalytic and enabling quality.

Finally, if we suppose provisionally that the mutant genes are dominant just as often as they are recessive, selection will be far more severe in eliminating the disadvantageous dominants than in eliminating the disadvantageous recessives.
